column5: Not going to touch that one. Don't believe I'll ever be calling any small bluegills that. Especially around any women. Some might be so offended they may use a certain part of your body for bait.

Northern Pike - Pike, Northerns Walleye - Pickerel, Eyes, Smallmouth Bass - Smallies, Bronzebacks Largemouth Bass - Thumpers Basically any Panfish - Bluegill Muskellunge - Skiis, Musky Brook Trout - Brookies Rainbow Trout - Bows Brown Trout - Browns These are pretty common where I live in Canada.
Small Bluegil=Guntcover
Never heard that one before. Looked up the word and no definition so I'm guessing there's a story behind the name? Never heard a largemouth bass called a "thumper" either.

Pike- water wolf, wolf, esox lucius, toothy critter (usually used when they cut our lines while jigging for walleye), snake Walleye- Walter, wally Perch- Percy Lake trout- Laker Smallmouth- Smally, Bronzeback, Football (only big ones) These are the ones that come off the top of my head, I'm sure there's more!

At least a few times during a typical trip to Canada, we refer to smallies as small eyes, only because it rhymes so well with walleyes and it just seems to flow off the tongue. Of course it is usually followed by I mean small mouth.
That's funny because sometimes I do just the opposite. When smallie fishing we occasionally catch a "wallie". Or I'll text my son or friends and say I caught 10 smallies and 1 wallie.

This is an entertaining Thread, the only one I can think of that hasn't been mentioned is where a Lake Trout is called a "Greaser". On a more humorous note, to the woman, I explain the difference between a Large Mouth Bass and a Small Mouth Bass; The "small mouth" Bass are the Males....... My favorite is the Snot Rocket, lol

Thanks, this thread has been mainly all freshwater species so I thought I might extend this to include saltwater species. I'm not real familiar with too many saltwater fish but a couple I can think of are redfish/drum and mahi mahi/dorado/dolphin (the fish, not flipper). Some more freshwater fish I didn't see mentioned (probably because it also gets no respect) is the rock bass, it is sometimes called a "red eye" for obvious reasons. Also the freshwater drum is referred to a sheepshead here in Michigan. White bass are sometimes called silver bass. Sunfish are called red ears (again for obvious reasons). Carp, suckers, gar, bowfin, are called rough fish or garbage fish here.
As someone posted above we often refer to a walleye as a "Walter".
Remove the G and insert a C. That's what all small fish are called in my boat. The first time I heard the term was on lake Michigan. It applied to small coho salmon.

Yeah I've heard of all of those and used most of them except I've not heard a smallmouth called a "browny" though some of the ones I've caught I can see by their color why it would be called that. I usually call smallmouth bass "smallies".
In french, at least here in Quebec walleye are called "doré jaune" saugers are "doré noir" jaune=yellow, noir=black Might as well add that pike in french is "brochet"

Pike - Slime Rockets - I wish I could take credit for this one. One of the owners from Ghost River Lodge referred to Pike as Slime Rockets. The name stuck and every pike ever since is a slime rocket. We love fishing for big pike. Lake Trout - Grease balls or bowling balls or CWOT's (Complete waste of time)
The only one I can think of that hasn't already been named is crappie.... speckle backs.
Lake trout are commonly called Togue in Northern New England.
I call them Lunch.

Medium sized pike who flop around relentlessly twisting up lines, nets, lures, and cut your fingers to pieces are called .... well, lots of things I can't repeat that usually include the words 'dirty whore' and 'filthy piece of #$%^'.

In Manitoba Burbot are called "Mariah". Walleye are still called incorrectly Pickerel, Nothern Pike are jacks, slime buckets, hammer handles and in the North "Paddlefish", because you use a paddle to kill them.
Burbots are called "lawyers" in some circles. Not sure why, but I can imagine a few reasons.
Fresh water cod, also known as "Ling", tasty but ugly.

If your old enough....there used to be a fair amount of semi trucks on the road that were COE "cab over engine" the ones that that are flat,square front end, big Sunnys look that way a little mouth with a tall square forehead.

Northern regardless of the size are called Snakes. Anyone that catches more than one northern is called a " snake charmer ". Walleye are called walleye. With the utmost respect to our fishing brethren up nort, this site would be called Pickrel Central otherwise. Bream are Bream. ( This covers sunfish, bluegills, shellcrackers ) Jackfish is a jackfish ( southern version of a northern) Peckerhead.......any fish that nibbles on your bait with no reward........relentlessly. PjShorthorn

Pike seem to get no respect, but large pike over 30" and bigger are my favorite target when I head to Canada. Some other names of fish I thought of when I was in Alaska the five Pacific salmon each had two names. Coho/silver, chinook/king, sockeye/red, pink/ humpback, and chum/dog. Sometimes the locals called a small salmon that followed the spawners in before it was old enough to spawn a "Jack". Also I fished for true "steelhead" which is a sea run rainbow trout that lives it's life in saltwater and spawns in freshwater. Burbot had several different names, freshwater cod, lingfish or ling. Bowfin/dogfish

Walleye- Dora, Pike -Jacks, both are toothy critters,both are also called shore lunch, Beer is called Blue, not to be confused with blue walleye, Add in a few cigars, A great day of fishing its called Heaven

Isn't the French or Quebec word for walleye dore? I have not heard of Dora before. Another one I forgot about, here in Michigan we call a Burbot an eelpout. Also brook trout are called specks, speckled trout, or brookies. I call them breakfast.
Northern Pike aka "Mr. Toothy".

Our terms: Walleye = Eye Big walleye = Mongo Small pike = --- ---- slimy ----! Large pike = Just a Pike The last one devolved from a fly in over 20 years ago when a buddy fought a fish on a jig and 6 lb. test for at least 10 minutes without ever seeing it. It went on long enough that our 2 other boats stopped fishing and drove closer to watch the show. His dad was in the boat with him. When they finally saw the fish his dad said, "It's just a pike." He put the net down and cast his own jig back out. When my buddy finally netted the pike on his own it measured 42".
42", just a pike? Lol. Like I said, no respect.

If someone in my boat catches a northern, I have no problem...unless: s/he has to bring it into my boat...then it is a $5 fine. Several of my fishin' buddies owe me lots of $, but I have never seen a dime of it...
Smallmouth Bass - Bronzeback, Browny Largemouth Bass - bucket mouth Large Northern Pike - Gator Walleye - Waldo, Wally, Marble Eyes

Another post made me think of different names people call the same common fish in North America. For example, I've heard small northern pike called jacks, snot rockets, slime buckets, and I've always called them snakes. Some people especially Canadians and those from northern states call walleyes, pickerel, yellow pickerel, or pike perch. Crappies are called calico bass and paper mouths. Bluegills, bream etc. what are some of the local names for commonly caught fish that you have heard?
Small pike=hammer handles
Oh yeah, I forgot about that one. I use it all the time also.

My dad tends to mix his metaphors. Knowing Canadians often refer to pike as jack and walleye as pickerel, to this day he still calls a small northern a jack handle. I stopped correcting him once he hit 80.
Northern = swamp donkey
Northerns are "honkees" in my boat. Sauger are mud rockets.
Pikes - slough sharks
Also known as Slimers! 14 to 16 inch walleye that's called lunch!
Big sunfish 10"+ Cabovers.
Cabovers? Where does that come from and mean? Never heard that one before.
